Baroque musicians were practical people, adapting or re-arranging music for different venues, instruments, singers quite frequently (both of Bach's passions, as well as Händel's Messiah, are known to have had this kind of treatment - and it is usually possible to reconstruct the different versions). This practicality is the key to the answer here for the differences between different bass parts, and has little to do with Schenker or any modern theories.In cases like the above, I think its possible to group the "changes" in three large categories:Adaptations due to range:Instruments do not all have the same range, even if they are roughly in the same register. Singers, notably, are not very comfortable singing very low, nor very audible doing so: big bass instruments like the violone (double bass) and the pipe organ (when played not as one too often sees today on a small positive, but on the big church organ, as would have been done at the time) however add quite a lot to the music when doing so. You see this all the time in chorales, where the bass voice stays one octave higher while the continuo jumps down for a few notes, the two usually recombining when appropriate. In your example, this is exactly what's happening in the second system, mes. 2-3.One will also frequently see this in the organ part: the lowest note one sees on organs is usually the C just below the bass clef. Considering that, in Leipzig at least, it was tuned one whole tone higher than the instruments (the part, when the manuscript part has survived to the present day, is almost always transposed one tone lower), this inevitably leads to frequent cases where a low c or c-sharp (resp. b-flat and b required on the organ) in the continuo is just not available on the organ: the whole line or fragment thereof is then moved up an octave to suit the range of the instrument.Simplifications due to different instrumental capabilities/functions: Beyond the mere question of range, not everything will sound great on every instrument, particularly in the bass register: for ex., the larger pipes on an organ need some time to 'speak' properly. In addition, the role of the continuo as the harmonic foundation of the whole piece would be very much weakened if the line were disturbed every few notes with ornaments (difficult to get exactly right between multiple players when rehearsal time is limited, as it was back then) and passing figures. This is why you will often see the vocal bass line (sung by the capable singers which Bach had at his disposition) simplified in the instrumental continuo, at least in large movements with orchestra and choir.
